data.body: I found a reproduceable bug with the Syntax Highlighting. The language i used was HTML+ERB. Haven't tested it yet in other languages. ![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5446019/4419401/5e9d43e4-456a-11e4-90d3-dcae6e13d910.gif) How you can see the commented part losses the "comment style" when i write the first `` in the wrong indent after a copy & paste. If i delete the comment beginning `

data.title: opening atom from terminal in tmux
data.body:
LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application /Applications/Atom.ap│~  
p with error -10810.

data.title: Project Find results don't display properly if you collapse files
data.body:
I'm using version 0.129.0 on a new MacBook Pro, with OSX 10.9.5

Whenever I perform a "Find in Project" command: ⌘⇧F
a new tab is opened titled "Project FindResults".
This tab contains the matches, arranged per file.

I've noticed two different and inconsistent behaviors:
- If I start collapsing match sets by file (click the v to change it to >),  
  the files collapse properly, but any files that were not already displayed in the panel
  will not show up as I continue to collapse match sets by file. 
  This leads to not being able to see all of the matches.
- If, instead, I scroll to the bottom first,  
  I can see all of the matches. Then the collapsing works as expected.
  And regardless of the order in which I collapse match sets by file,
  I can find all of the matches.

data.title: Font too small on QHD screen
data.body:
Hello, I am running Atom (or trying it) on Linux (Xubuntu 14.04.1 64b) with a QHD screen. The problem is that GUI fonts are too small to work with it.

![sshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/189494/4413993/cafefef8-450e-11e4-9a9f-ed350d7d5b8e.png)

Thanks

data.title: Fix Copy / Cut's accelerators on Win32
data.body: Copy/Cut/Paste always have the same accelerator in every app, '_Copy', 'Cu_t', '_Paste'

data.title: Use custom elements for workspace views
data.body:
This is the next step in removing dependency on jQuery in core. It replaces all the SpacePen views with custom elements in the workspace. The SpacePen views are left in place as wrapper shims that we will deprecate, but they no longer contain essential logic. For now this uses the `is` attribute with the elements subclassing `div`s for styling compatibility. In another pass we will convert them to custom tag names. The following views have been converted:
- `WorkspaceView` => `WorkspaceElement`
- `PaneContainerView` => `PaneContainerElement`
- `PaneColumnView` and `PaneRowView` => `PaneAxisElement`
- `PaneView` => `PaneElement`

data.title: Deleting a symlink removes the target
data.body:
If you delete a symlink in the file tree, it will remove both the symlink and the file that the symlink points to. The expected action would be to remove the symlink while leaving the destination file intact.

Version: 0.129.0

Unsure if this is present in other versions, as I just found the issue.

data.title: Set default path to open on linux
data.body:
Mirrors behavior of other applications on Ubuntu that offer Open File and Open Folder commands.

Closes #3618

data.title: New File Error
data.body:
When I try to create a new file, I receive the following error:

``` bash
TypeError: DOM object constructor cannot be called as a function.
  at TypeError (native)
  at new SublimeTabView (/Users/abretz/.atom/packages/sublime-tabs/lib/sublime-tab-view.coffee:9:3)
  at SublimeTabBarView.module.exports.SublimeTabBarView.addTabForItem (/Users/abretz/.atom/packages/sublime-tabs/lib/sublime-tab-bar-view.coffee:37:19)
  at HTMLDivElement.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/tabs/lib/tab-bar-view.js:86:17)
  at HTMLDivElement.jQuery.event.dispatch (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4676:9)
  at HTMLDivElement.elemData.handle (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4360:46)
  at Object.jQuery.event.trigger (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4594:12)
  at HTMLDivElement.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:5119:17)

  at PaneView.module.exports.PaneView.onItemAdded (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane-view.js:347:19)
  at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane-view.js:3:61
  at Emitter.module.exports.Emitter.emit (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/event-kit/lib/emitter.js:71:11)
  at Pane.module.exports.Pane.addItem (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:320:20)
  at Pane.module.exports.Pane.activateItem (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:299:14)
  at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace.js:367:16

```

I am using version 0.131.0 and I just updated today.

data.title: Resize cursor doesn't appear in tree view.
data.body:
In windows, the resize cursor doesn't appear for the tree view.
![cursor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4172079/4403436/23ceb5b2-44a3-11e4-8c2f-5d31cf94e267.gif)

data.title: Insane amount of max_user_watches required to run Atom on Ubuntu 14.04
data.body:
Follow up to #3617 . Ubuntu 14.04 with latest updates and Atom 0.130.0.

Problem was fixed as instructed in #3617 and re-appeared later and `max_user_watches` is still being set at new value 32768.

```
$ cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_watches 
32768
```

While Atom was open, it just failed to open any new files. After closing it, it has reverted to state I first reported #3617, failing to open at all.

Setting `max_user_watches` to `131072` allowed me to run Atom again. But why such high values are required for a simple text editor? Is code leaking watches, or establishing watches too widely?

data.title: Editor crashes on saving or on opening a file that has been modified
data.body:
In the last 2 days, Atom has started to:
- Crash immediately after saving an edited file
- Crash whenever you try to open a file that has been modified but not committed (according to git) - verified by committing the file and then trying to open it, which then works

It appears to have issues reconciling the git status of the file on opening or saving, maybe? I'm not using any complex arrangement of plugins.

data.title: File chooser dialog is not modal and does not have focus on Ubuntu 14.04
data.body:
On Ubuntu 14.04, Atom 0.130.0, if you do "ctrl-o" to open a file, the file chooser dialog does not become focused nor modal. 

It means you cannot cancel the dialog with quick press of "esc" or you cannot choose files with keyboard input only, but you need to be clicking it with a mouse to get focus.

Checking Sublime, gedit, Firefox or basically any app, file chooser dialog is always modal and has focus.

data.title: `cmd-l` `cmd-c` `cmd-v` strips indentation
data.body:
Expected behavior: 
`cmd-l` `cmd-c` `cmd-v` (selecting the current line, copying the current line, and pasting it over the top of itself) should leave no changes to the editor.

Current behavior:
After this key combo, the current line is stripped of its previous indentation.

Why it's useful:
I often use this command along with additional presses of `cmd-v` in order to duplicate the current line in-place.  

For one example, I use it when adding vendor prefixes in CSS.
**Sublime** (`cmd-l c v v v` to paste 3 times)
![Sublime](http://cl.ly/image/131f3J3o241b/Screen%20Recording%202014-09-24%20at%2008.03%20PM.gif)

Atom loses my indentation when I paste the same line over the top of itself.
**Atom**
![Atom](http://cl.ly/image/310D0L182j36/Screen%20Recording%202014-09-24%20at%2008.06%20PM.gif)

data.title: cmd-l in multi-line selection doesn't select beginning of first line
data.body:
When you you have no selection, with a cursor in the middle of a line, `cmd-l` selects the entire line, from the left side of the editor to the right side, including the ending newline.

When you have a selection that spans a few lines, `cmd-l` selects the end of the last line, but doesn't select the beginning of the first line.  I expected it to select the beginning of the first line too.
![Screen capture](http://cl.ly/image/042j0S2T1t04/Screen%20Recording%202014-09-24%20at%2007.47%20PM.gif)

data.title: [Windows] Font should become more sharp
data.body: The Windows version has some text, in some dialogs, that should be more sharp.

data.title: Cursor position disappears when window loses focus
data.body: I'm on Ubuntu 14.04 and every time I alt+tab or make Atom lose focus in any way, the cursor position disappears.  I have to click on the window to make it reappear.

data.title: Editing longest line repaints entire editor
data.body:
The entire editor area repaints on every keystroke when the cursor is on the longest line in the file.

Not sure if this can be avoided since I assume it is updating some width calculation.

![repaint-longest-line](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/671378/4397288/02af9ac6-4440-11e4-9482-bdf6f78863d1.gif)

/cc @nathansobo we talked briefly about this and thought initially it was an issue when editing the first line but it appears to be related to longest line editing.

data.title: Uncaught Error: No screen line exists when converting buffer row to screen row (display-buffer.js:932)
data.body:
I continue to get this error in spite of disabling many of the packages installed on Atom. I had hoped it would be fixed in the last several releases, but it has not been. 

The error I receive is:

Uncaught Error: No screen line exists when converting buffer row to screen row
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/display-buffer.js:932

Please help!

data.title: Add ability to scroll past the end of the file
data.body:
Fixes #3592 

Since @thedaniel [suggested](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3592#issuecomment-56398349) that this should be part of the default behavior, I took some of the code from the [scroll-past-end package](https://atom.io/packages/scroll-past-end) and added the functionality.

data.title: ctrl-o in Ubuntu always opens "Recently Used" in file chooser
data.body:
Using keyboard shortcut `ctrl-o` in Ubuntu launches open file dialog with "Recently used" as default folder. The default in basically all other apps (including Sublime Text) is to open the currently open file's folder as default.

Yes, the tree view is there to quickly open files from current directory, but breaking convention is bad.

data.title: Atom on Trusty is completely broken
data.body:
![screenshot from 2014-09-24 12 37 43](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/853790/4386268/78e10fa8-43ce-11e4-8bd8-d987e53acac1.png)

Didn't use Atom for a while on my Ubuntu Trusty. Now on version 0.130.0, packaged by webupd8team from their PPA, Atom UI is completely broken. Uninstalling and reinstalling didn't work, nor did removing `.atom` in my `$HOME` etc.

Menu for Atom includes only one `Atom` menu with items:
- Check for update
- Reload
- Close window
- Toggle dev tools
- Quit

data.title: Atom not focused correctly on launch
data.body:
I'm using Atom 0.130 on Ubuntu 14.04 with Unity.  When running Atom the application will come to the foreground but it isn't correctly focused - the title and left launcher show the previously focused application.  Steps to replicate:
- Open an application that isn't atom
- Run atom from the dash
- See the title bar/launcher still thinking the previous application is focused.

The image below shows the issue - I had Firefox focused before opening Atom.

![atom-focus](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/422013/4385353/9d19127c-43c3-11e4-837d-648960f14b7d.png)

data.title: tabs are hidden behind vertically split panes
data.body:
1. Open Atom and open a bunch of tabs (took 11 for me to see this bug)
2. split panes vertically
3. go to the last (11th) tab on the left pane

expected: you can see the tab of the file you're on

actual: the tab is hidden behind the right pane

![screen shot 2014-09-23 at 8 32 11 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/407222/4383192/667af8fc-439b-11e4-9243-f73d387f7adc.png)

Atom 0.130
OS X 10.9.4

data.title: Star a package from within Atom
data.body: You should be able to star a package on your account through _Preferences > Packages_. Right now it seems the quickest way to do this is to click "Learn More" so you are taken to the Atom website and can star it there.

data.title: Support JSON Schema in Config
data.body:
JSON Schema ([schema core](http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-core.html), and the [supported keys](http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-validation.html))

It will look like this:

``` coffee
@config:
  fontSize:
    type: 'integer'
    default: 16
  lineHeight:
    type: 'number'
    default: 1.3
  someArray:
    type: 'array'
    default: ['ok', 'yeah']
    items:
      type: 'string'
  invisibles:
    type: 'object'
    properties:
      eol:
        type: 'string'
        default: '\u00ac'
      space:
        type: 'string'
        default: '\u00b7'
```
### Notes
- If a value is passed to `::set` cannot be coerced, it will not be set (eg. passing `'omg'` to an integer type)
### TODO
- [x] support some of the fancy bits of the schema (minimum, maximum, enum)
- [x] deprecate the `getInt` style methods
- [x] use in our internal classes
- [x] read schema from loaded packages
- [x] figure out a reasonable notification when there are issues loading user's config
- [x] deprecate `configDefaults`
- [x] write a doc about it I can point to
- [x] write good docs into Config class
- [x] Move config schemas out of workspace and editor
- [x] convert a package to use schema in a PR https://github.com/atom/git-diff/pull/40
- [x] make sure settings view works

data.title: space pen bug in 0.130.0 (tabBarView broken)
data.body:
As of 130 these two lines of code evaluate to the same thing.  In both cases it is an element when one should be a view. 

![space](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/811455/4382240/20e05a5a-4385-11e4-89a2-41d7a086dbc7.gif)

Even if things were changed on purpose, why would `.view()` even be defined on an element if it just returns the element?

This has broken my live-archive app and I'm not sure what would be the correct fix.

data.title: Activation commands
data.body:
## Remaining Work
- [x] Fix failing specs due to jQuery `trigger` being called for commands instead of native event dispatch.
## Description

This PR properly integrates the new global command registry (`atom.commands`) with package activation events. It does the following:
- Switches the syntax of `atom.activationEvents` to `atom.activationCommands`. This hash has mandatory selectors mapping to strings or arrays of strings as follows:

``` coffee
  activationCommands: {
    ".workspace": [
      "project-find:show",
      "project-find:toggle",
      "project-find:show-in-current-directory",
      # ...
    ]
  }
```
- Uses `atom.commands` instead of `$::command` to listen for package activation. This means we won't need to use a deprecated API to support this behavior when we deprecate `atom.workspaceView` and `$::command`.
- Ensures that commands registered with `atom.commands` are invoked only once even when the activation command is replayed after activating the package.

This is delicate work but I'm pretty sure it preserves existing behavior. Specs pass and I tried a handful of baked-in packages without issues. The last remaining issue is to deal with specs that call `trigger` to invoke commands, which isn't picked up by our native handlers. I'd like to find a way to enhance jQuery's `trigger` to invoke real DOM events. One nice thing: Because the command registry uses the [capture phase](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget.addEventListener) of events, we don't need to disable the jQuery event listeners anymore to prevent them from being invoked twice. We stop propagation of the activation command and reinvoke it after activating the package. It's this second invocation that ends up calling listeners registered via jQuery.

data.title: Don't override antialiasing in markdown
data.body: Not sure if there is a reason for these.
